body: Hey @ricardoboss, can you reproduce the issue on https://psalm.dev ?
Yeah, I can reproduce it... but why? https://psalm.dev/r/d757d80ca9

Also, if I add:
```
/**
 * @psalm-suppress InvalidConstantAssignmentValue
 */
```

to the class, it still reports the errors. Is this supposed to work? It also doesn't work if I add it to each individual const, reporting each as unused next to the error I want to suppress.

milestone.title: PSR Compatibility
milestone.description: This milestone tracks the completion of 100% PSR compatible packages.

body: @AndrolGenhald That's weird, seems like the property is analyzed twice with two different values for the calculation

Yeah, I've run into this before but most of the issues were fixed. I think the problem is that it's being resolved once by `ClassLikeNodeScanner` using `SimpleTypeInferer` to infer the type, then it's being resolved again when evaluating the assignment, and for some reason the assignment evaluation isn't as specific. I'll see if I can take a look at it this week.

If it helps: the order matters!

Moving the `DAYS_PER_MONTH` const above all others doesn't produce the error.
As does moving `SECONDS_PER_MONTH` to the bottom, looks like the analysis isn't working correctly when constants are used before they're declared.
Apart from the consts, what about the `psalm --alter` suggestion? Is this just not implemented (yet)?
I'm not sure what's going on there, I don't think that issue should even be showing up as fixable. I'll look into that as well.

Turns out the issue is in BinaryOpAnalyzer, it calculates literal expressions [for ints](https://psalm.dev/r/8d96dc0dca) but not [for floats](https://psalm.dev/r/4676f17236). The constant type inferrer gets the literal type when determining the constant's type, but then when the statement is later analyzed to make sure the assignment matches the constant's type it doesn't calculate the literal type, so it doesn't match. Working on a fix.

issue.title: IssueBuffer should handle fixable issues itself

labels.name: easy problems
labels.description: Issues that can be fixed without background knowledge of Psalm

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.body:
#7973 suggested `psalm --alter` for an unfixable issue due to a copy/paste fail where a non-fixable issue was added to the issue buffer with `$is_fixable = true`. Given that `ProjectAnalyzer::SUPPORTED_ISSUES_TO_FIX` already tracks which issues are fixable, I think that should be made public and `IssueBuffer` can use that to determine fixability instead of relying on the caller to specify.

The only reason I can think of not to do this is if there are any issues that are listed as fixable, but where we don't want a specific instance of that issue to be fixable, is that ever the case?
